Award.AwardTitle: Statistical inference for space-time models involving stochastic differential equations
Award.AbstractNarration:
Many fields have experienced a recent growth in the use of stochastic differential equations (SDEs) to model scientific phenomena over time. Examples include applications in oceanography, ecology, and public health. SDEs can simultaneously capture the known deterministic dynamics of the variables of interest (e.g., ocean flow, the chemical and physical characteristics of a body of water, the presence, absence and spread of a disease), while enabling a modeler to capture the unknown dynamics and measurement processes in a stochastic setting. This proposal develops statistical methodology for building, fitting, and diagnosing the fit of multivariate and spatially-varying SDEs. Such models, which are often inspired by mechanistic modeling, can incorporate the complex dynamics of the variables of interest.

Although statistical methods for the fitting and analysis of SDEs models using data at a single location are becoming more widely used, accurate statistical methods for multivariate SDEs and SDEs indexed in space are far less developed. This project will derive improved approximate methods of inference for one- and multi-dimensional SDEs that are more accurate than the commonly used, but naive, Euler approximations. Spatially-varying SDE models will be built for modeling spatio-temporal data observed potentially irregularly in space and time. This research will be applied to address problems in applied disciplines. Education of students in statistical methods for SDEs will be an important goal of this project. In addition, a number of outreach programs will be used to educate a broader audience.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Many fields have experienced a recent growth in the use of stochastic differential equations (SDEs) to model scientific phenomena over time. Examples include applications in oceanography, ecology, and public health. SDEs can simultaneously capture the known deterministic dynamics of the variables of interest (e.g., ocean flow, animal dynamics, and modeling genetic drift), while enabling a modeler to capture the unknown dynamics and measurement processes in a probabilistic setting. 

This research project developed statistical methodology for building, fitting, and diagnosing the fit of multivariate and spatially-varying SDEs. Such models, which are often inspired by mechanistic modeling, can incorporate the complex dynamics of the variables of interest.   The project developed approximate methods of inference for one- and multi-dimensional SDEs that are more accurate than the commonly used, but naive, Euler approximations. Our methodology is fully probabilistic and it naturally lends itself to quantifying uncertainty in a principled way. Throughout the duration of the project we have used a series of examples from oceanography, population genetics, ecology and in each case have provided estimates of unknown quantities along with measures of uncertainty which are easily interpretable.

There were five specific aims of this project: (1) Maximum likelihood estimation for SDE using sequential Gaussian process-based optimization; (2) Exact inference for the Wright-Fisher model; (3) Statistical inference for continuous spatio-temporal stochastic processes; (4) Exact statistical inference for a class of multivariate diffusions; (5) Exact inference for functional parameters.  All these projects were completed.  In each aim, the research was applied to address challenging problems in applied disciplines.

A number of graduate students were educated in statistical methods for SDEs.  A workshop, organized in concert with the Mathematical Biosciences Institute was held to educate graduate students in SDEs.  This led to the training of students in Statistics, Ecology, Environmental Sciences and Hydrology.     Research publications in a number of different fields in spatio-temporal statistics were produced.   A number of conference presentations were given on this work. In addition, throughout the duration of the project we developed efficient computer code which is freely available to the research community.
